item.title: Evidence of early medieval Muslim graves found in France
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Archaeological and genetic analysis may indicate that three skeletons buried in medieval graves in France may have been Muslim, according to a study published February 24, 2016 in the open-access journal PLOS ONE by Yves Gleize from the French National Institute for Preventive Archaeological Research (Inrap) and University of Bordeaux, France, Fanny Mendisco from University of Bordeaux, France, and colleagues.

item.title: Conservatives prefer using nouns, new research finds
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Conservatives prefer using nouns, new transatlantic research suggests. The research also established that conservatives generally, to a greater degree than liberals, tend to refer to things by their names, rather than describing them in terms of their features. An example would be saying someone ‘is an optimist’, rather than ‘is optimistic’.

item.title: Astronomers Finally Pinpoint the Location of Mysterious Radio Bursts in Space
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: FRBs or “fast radio bursts” are extremely energetic pulses that only last for a few milliseconds. They’ve only been observed 17 times from random points in the sky. Now, a report in Nature shows that astronomers have been able to pinpoint the location of one that released two days worth of our Sun’s energy in a fraction of a second.

item.title: Cardiologists use 3-D printing to personalize treatment for heart disease -- ScienceDaily
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Supercomputers are being used by clinicians to create 3-D models from patients with heart disease, with photos from a camera thinner than a human hair.

item.title: Wild gorillas compose happy songs that they hum during meals | New Scientist
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Gorillas sing and hum when eating, a discovery that could help shed light on how language evolved in early humans. Singing seems to be a way for gorillas to express contentment with their meal, as well as for the head of the family to communicate to others that it is dinner time.

item.title: One-Year Crew Returns from Space Station March 1; Live Coverage on NASA TV
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Don’t miss it: NASA Television will provide complete coverage Tuesday, March 1, as three crew members depart the International Space Station, including NASA astronaut Scott Kelly and cosmonaut Mikhail Kornienko of the Russian space agency Roscosmos – the station’s first one-year crew.

item.title: Human survivors of Ebola may offer clue to effective treatment
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Human survivors of the Ebola might be the key to creating an effective therapy for those infected with the disease. A new study published in Science shows how antibodies target part of a protein on the surface of the Ebola virus and treating the infection in mice.

item.title: FeedPress is Analytics and Podcast Hosting
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Hosting and feed support provided by Feed.Press. Sign-up today and try FeedPress on a 14 day trial (no contracts or commitments). Use promo code morningshow during checkout to get 10% off your first year.

item.title: Researchers develop new nanoparticle with potential to treat ocular cancer
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Researchers at the University of Michigan Kellogg Eye Center have developed a new nanoparticle that uses a tumor cell’s protective mechanism against itself—short-circuiting tumor cell metabolism and killing tumor cells.

item.title: President Obama honors early career scientists with top White House award
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: President Obama has named the 106 recipients of the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers; the highest award for scientists and engineers in the early stages of their research career. The award recipients come from universities around the country and study subjects including biology, computer and information science, education and human resources, engineering, and more

item.title: NASA Scientists, Engineers Receive Presidential Early Career Awards
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: President Obama Thursday named six NASA researchers as recipients of the 2016 Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers (PECASE). These recipients, and 100 other federal researchers, will receive their awards in a ceremony later this year in Washington.

item.title: What Chocolate Looks Like When Viewed Under a Scanning Electron Microscope
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Graduate student Jennifer Dailey talks about a class she has been teaching at Johns Hopkins University that focuses on the subject of chocolate, what it consists of, its various melting points and even what it looks like under a scanning electron microscope.

item.title: Functional biomarker for age-related macular degeneration found
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: A new study has found adults whose eyes are slow to adjust to the dark have a greater risk of developing age-related macular degeneration; blurring of the center of vision.

item.title: Cambits, a modular imaging system that can transform into many different cameras
item.author: Kyle Roderick
item.description: Cambits, a modular imaging system that can transform into many different cameras, developed by Columbia Engineering Computer Science Professor Shree Nayar and Makoto Odamaki, visiting scientist from Ricoh Corporation.
